makers.displaydate: 1911–2004; born Schiedam, Netherlands; died Rotterdam, Netherlands
makers.displaymaker: Steef Zoetmulder, 1911–2004; born Schiedam, Netherlands; died Rotterdam, Netherlands

texts.textentryhtml: Purchased by Alexander D. Stuart, March 9, 1991; gifted by Alexander D. Stuart, Class of 1972, and Robin Stuart to Princeton University Art Museum, October 2023.

Zoetmulder’s close-up of a porcelain cup and saucer renders these objects in precise, sharp detail, with the domestic interior they occupy reflected and distorted on the saucer’s shiny surface. The image indicates the photographer’s indebtedness to the New Objectivity movement in photography, which sought to depict objects in a sharp, realistic light. Like many photographers associated with this movement, which emerged in Germany in the 1920s, Zoetmulder sought to cultivate a language of photographic seeing. He once wrote, “Photography is a discrete and independent field with its own design principles . . .thus photography is distinct from other modes of expression such as painting.”
